titlestmt.titleproper:
Preliminary Guide to the Richard Irvin & Co. Records
circa 1824-1939
(bulk, 1860s-1919)
MS 324
titlestmt.author: Elise Winks and Joseph Ditta

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-25 10:04:55 -0400.

physdesc.extent: in 10 document boxes (7 full and 3 half-size), 88 record cartons, and 394 volumes.

did.abstract: Business records of New York City commission merchants and bankers Richard Irvin & Co., headed by Scottish immigrant Richard Irvin (1799–1888), his son, Richard Irvin Jr. (1840–1896), and grandson, Richard Irvin III (1869–1938), between about 1824 and 1939. Richard Irvin & Co. was the sole New York consignee of Gartsherrie Iron supplied by William Baird & Co. of Glasgow, and agents for the Great Western Steamship Company, which instituted the first regular transatlantic steamer service in 1838–1846. Among the collection is evidence of the firm's extensive business with Gibbs, Bright & Co. of Liverpool, and with Samuel Irvin & Co. of Glasgow; their exports to Bright Bros. & Co. of Melbourne and Sydney, Australia; their trade with Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, Canada; their activities as New York agents for Satterthwaite & Co., stock and share brokers of London; their exclusive foreign representation of the Maxwell automobile; their brokerage of the guano and nitrate trade between England and South America; and their interest in the manufacture of pneumatic cushions and mattresses, and railway cars for export to Santo Domingo.

physloc.emph: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly. Also, most of the boxed material consists of tied bundles of unprocessed, trifold documents, which will require opening and flattening by staff before viewing.

did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers, who should be aware that the collection is not processed. Materials remain largely in the condition in which they arrived at the New-York Historical Society in 1945 and 1950, namely, in countless tied bundles of bills, receipts, insurance policies, and trifold correspondence. Many of the 394 volumes, which were shrinkwrapped in 2019-2020 for off-site storage, lack dates or identifying information on their exteriors.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Misses Frances Irvin and Clara Irvin, 1945 and 1950.

The donors were the granddaughters of Richard Irvin (1799–1888) and sisters of Richard Irvin III (1869–1938). For details of their gift, see Annual Report of The New-York Historical Society for the Year 1945, 18, 32-33, 45; The New-York Historical Society Quarterly vol. 30, no. 1 (January 1946), 60; and Annual Report of The New-York Historical Society for the Year 1950, 55.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized by format in two series:

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Glasgow native Richard Irvin (1799–1888), son of William and Janet (Scott) Irvin, left Scotland in 1824 to join the shipping business his uncle, Thomas Irvin, had established in New York in 1787. At the death of Thomas in 1836, Richard assumed control, and brought two of his sons—Alexander P. and Richard Irvin Jr.—into the firm. About 1840 they became the sole New York consignees of the Gartsherrie Iron supplied by William Baird & Co. of Glasgow, one of the United Kingdom's largest iron dealers. They were also New York agents for the Great Western Steamship Company, which instituted the first regular transatlantic steamer service via the vessels SS Great Western and SS Great Britain in 1838–1846.

By 1863 the firm—then known as Richard Irvin & Co.—had expanded from its original commission business to banking. Richard Irvin served as a director of the Mechanics' National Bank for fifty years, and was the oldest member of the New York Chamber of Commerce (having joined in 1834) when he died in 1888.

Son Richard Irvin Jr. (1840–1896), who carried on the business after his father's death, had philanthropic and cultural interests. He provided financial support to numerous organizations, among them the Bach Singers of New York, the Cantata Club, and the American School of Opera.

At Richard Irvin Jr.'s death, the firm was revived by his nephew, Richard Irvin III (1869–1938). A banker like his uncle and grandfather, Richard III was one of the organizers and a former treasurer of the Maxwell-Briscoe Motor Company, an early manufacturer of automobiles. Richard Irvin & Co. folded with his death. Richard's surviving sisters, Frances and Clara, donated the firm's business records to the New-York Historical Society in 1945.

[This note draws on Richard Irvin Sr.'s Wikipedia entry, his obituary from The New York Times (June 29, 1888), and the Times obituaries of Richard Irvin Jr. (March 9, 1896, p. 5) and Richard Irvin III (May 25, 1938, p. 23). See also William M. MacBean, Biographical Register of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York (Printed for the Society, 1925), vol. 2, p. 98, entry 920, "Richard Irvin," and Arthur J. Breton, A Guide to the Manuscript Collections of The New-York Historical Society (Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, Inc., 1972), vol. 1, p. 465, entry 2857, "Richard Irvin & Co."]

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as: Richard Irvin & Co. Records, MS 324, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In October-December 1945, shortly after receiving the Richard Irvin & Co. Records, the New-York Historical Society engaged an intern from New York University, who was studying business archives administration, to survey and organize the collection. She got as far as creating a partial list of the 394 volumes, and typing detailed suggestions in a "Letter to My Successor" who might complete the task. (Her list of volumes and the letter may be found in box 98. A copy of the volume list is also kept at the Manuscript Reference desk.) Essentially, the collection remains unprocessed. As part of a project conducted in 2019-2020 to ready it for off-site storage, archivists Elise Winks and Joseph Ditta performed a high level survey. They transferred much of the collection from fifteen large, wooden, disorganized, and inaccessible trunks to more manageable record cartons, and described it broadly in this preliminary finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Richard Irvin (1799-1888) served as president of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York in 1842-1851 and 1862-1864. The Saint Andrew's Society, formed in 1756, is a fraternal and charitable organization whose members claim Scottish ancestry. See the New-York Historical Society's Guide to the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records, 1785-2014 (MS 2997).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the business records of Richard Irvin & Co., commission merchants and bankers of New York City, and spans the years 1824 through 1939, with the bulk of items appearing to cover the 1860s through about 1919. Descriptions of the collection made when it came to the New-York Historical Society (in two or possibly three accessions) and subsequent surveys suggest its outside date range of 1824–1939. But while the records might extend as far back as 1824, and into the late 1930s, the unprocessed state of the collection, particularly the bound volumes in Series II, makes it impossible to ascertain truly accurate dates. The earliest items observed while rehousing the collection dated from circa 1839; the latest, from circa 1919.

The collection includes letters received, letterpress copies of letters sent, account books of various kinds, insurance policies, bills of lading, gold checks, bills of exchange, receipts, invoices, etc. A sampling of the papers reveals: the firm's activities as agents for the sale of Gartsherrie and other iron and steel from England; their extensive business with Gibbs, Bright & Co. of Liverpool, and with Samuel Irvin & Co. of Glasgow; extensive exports to Bright Bros. & Co. of Melbourne and Sydney, Australia; trade with Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, Canada; their activities as New York agents for Satterthwaite & Co., stock and share brokers of London; as exclusive foreign representatives of the Maxwell automobile; agents of National Steel Co.; sole manufacturers of pneumatic cushions and mattresses; agents in the guano and nitrate trade between England and Peru, Chile, and Bolivia; agents for the sale of railway cars, particularly to the Samana & Santiago Railway Co., Santo Domingo; exporters to New Zealand; agents for Niagara Emery Mills, Inc., Lockport, New York; extensive transactions in stocks, bonds, and gold; etc.
[This note draws on Arthur J. Breton, A Guide to the Manuscript Collections of The New-York Historical Society (Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, Inc., 1972), vol. 1, 465, entry 2857.]

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains the day-to-day business records of Richard Irvin & Co., commission merchants and bankers of New York, spanning from about 1843 through 1919, but possibly dating from as early as 1824 and as late as 1939 (the 1824–1939 range is based on existing descriptions, but no materials from those outside years were observed while surveying the collection). Formats include bills of exchange, bills of lading (inward and outward), bonds, checks, commercial correspondence, insurance policies, invoices, orders to pay, receipts, stock certificates, and vouchers. The papers reveal the firm's myriad activities: as agents for the sale of iron and steel from England; their exporting and importing business with companies in Australia and Canada; their role as New York agents for Satterthwaite & Co., stock and share brokers of London; and as exclusive foreign representatives of the Maxwell-Briscoe Motor Company, early manufacturers of automobiles. Richard Irvin & Co. also had a hand in the manufacture of pneumatic cushions and mattresses, the construction and sale of railway cars, and the trade of guano and nitrate between England, Peru, Chile, and Bolivia. The container list records what information could be gleaned from the collection's sparsely identified bundles.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in boxes 1–34 appears to have been processed in late 1945 by a New York University intern (or a successor) engaged to organize the collection shortly after its accession (see her notes in Box 98). In 2019–2020, to prepare the collection for shipment to off-site storage, New-York Historical Society archivists transferred the material from boxes 11–33 to record cartons. They also transferred the contents of fifteen unwieldy wooden trunks to record cartons (boxes 35–98) while attempting to group their contents by type, e.g., correspondence, checks, insurance policies, bills of lading, statements of exchange, etc. Most material remains tied in trifold bundles and packets. Note that the trunk numbering mentioned in the container list was assigned by New-York Historical Society staff, and simply reflects the haphazard order in which the trunks were stacked; it has no bearing on the chronology of their contents. Similarly, the labeling and dates on the outside of most trunks bore little relation to what was inside, but has nevertheless been transcribed to preserve any possible historical significance.

odd.head: General
odd.p: A copy of the volume list is also kept at the Manuscript Reference desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains 394 bound volumes of a mostly financial and transactional nature, ranging from about 1848 through 1914, and, possibly, as early as 1824 and as late as 1939. The volumes include account books of various type (e.g., balances, bills payable, cash books, checkbooks, gold accounts, invoices, investments, ledgers, journals, sales, stocks and bonds, and ventures), letter books recording Richard Irvin & Co.'s voluminous commercial correspondence (bulk, 1865–1900), the occasional scrapbook of telegram and cable copies, and a handful of published books (such as Charles Ezra Sprague's Tables of Compound Interest, Discount, Annuities, Sinking Funds and Other Computations for use in the Accountancy of Investment).

The container list provides an inventory of all volumes. However, when the inventory was taken, all volumes had been shrink-wrapped for off-site storage. Consequently, the inventory is not based on a review of the volume content, but was drawn from a list assembled by a New York University intern who surveyed the collection in 1945, as well as any labeling visible on the spines, inferences, and other observations short of unwrapping the volumes. Thus, many are thus entered as "contents unknown." Inaccuracies, especially in date ranges, are likely. The absence of a date range in the container list means that no dates were observed on the exterior of the shrink-wrapped volume.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 2019-2020, in preparing the bound volumes of the collection for off-site storage, each volume was given a sequence number (SN), which simply indicated the order of the volumes as found on the shelves. This finding aid presents the volumes in that same order, with reference to the sequence number. Related volumes were often found together on the shelves, but there was also a considerable degree of randomness that is reflected in the container list. Parenthetical numbers following some titles represent Richard Irvin & Co.'s in-house organizational scheme.
